quotes.topic_title: Marketplace whac-a-mole and tradeoffs
quotes.text: Marketplaces are a little bit like a game of whac-a-mole.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why marketplace optimization is an ongoing, shifting set of tradeoffs rather than a one-time fix.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace whac-a-mole and tradeoffs
quotes.text: But then we're looking at it, we're like, "Wait a second. Now the existing folks on the other side are having a worse experience," so you kind of whiplash around.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Illustrates the practical reality that improving one side’s experience can degrade the other side’s, forcing constant rebalancing.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace whac-a-mole and tradeoffs
quotes.text: And that's because the whac-a-mole game here is ultimately, a lot of marketplace management is moving attention and inventory around.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A concrete framing of what marketplace interventions actually do: reallocate scarce attention and inventory.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace whac-a-mole and tradeoffs
quotes.text: Many of the changes that are most consequential create winners and losers.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that impactful marketplace changes are often zero-sum across cohorts, not universally beneficial.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace whac-a-mole and tradeoffs
quotes.text: And rolling with those changes is about recognizing whether the winners you've created are more important to your business than the losers you've created in the process.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for prioritization: evaluate changes by which cohorts you’re intentionally favoring and why.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And in our conversation, we get super nerdy on how to build a thriving marketplace, including where to focus your resources to fuel the marketplace flywheel growth, why data and data science is so central to building a successful marketplace, how to design a better review system.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights three concrete practitioner levers—resource focus for flywheel growth, data science as a core capability, and review-system design.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Why as a founder, you shouldn't think of yourself as a marketplace founder, but instead simply as a founder.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian identity/frame shift that can change how founders prioritize and make decisions beyond “marketplace-specific” playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, how AI is going to impact data science and marketplaces, and experimentation, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals a forward-looking methodology shift: AI’s influence on marketplace ops and the experimentation/data science stack.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Your website is the heart of your growth engine.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sanity)
quotes.context: A memorable framing that encourages teams to treat the website as a core growth system, not just a marketing asset.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For that engine to drive big results, you need to be able to move super fast, ship new content, experiment, learn and iterate.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sanity)
quotes.context: A practical operating model for growth: speed + continuous experimentation and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: As the most powerful headless CMS on the market, you can tailor editorial workflows to match your business, reuse content seamlessly across any page or channel, and bring your ideas to market without developer friction.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sanity)
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for scaling content ops: customize workflows, reuse content, and reduce engineering bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Hex brings everything together.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Hex)
quotes.context: A succinct principle for analytics productivity: consolidate fragmented workflows into one collaborative environment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And now Hex's, AI tools can generate queries and code, create visualizations, and even kickstart a whole analysis for you all from natural language prompts.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Hex)
quotes.context: An actionable AI workflow: use natural language to bootstrap analysis, code, and charts to reduce time-to-insight.

quotes.topic_title: Ramesh’s background and early marketplace data science
quotes.text: We're going to get super nerdy about marketplaces, and experimentation, and data.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets the episode’s practical focus on using experimentation and data as core tools for building and operating marketplaces.

quotes.topic_title: Ramesh’s background and early marketplace data science
quotes.text: I got to know Riley when I was at oDesk first as a research scientist, and then I directed their data science team.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner path from research to leading applied data science in a marketplace company.

quotes.topic_title: Ramesh’s background and early marketplace data science
quotes.text: This is way back in 2012, and I was looking around for people who are experts on how we think about data and marketplaces, and Riley Newman came up and so I invited him to come talk to us at oDesk, and we've stayed in touch since then.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Concrete example of proactively bringing in domain experts to level up marketplace data thinking—an actionable tactic for teams.

quotes.topic_title: Ramesh’s background and early marketplace data science
quotes.text: Those were early days of where this industry was, and I've had a kind of lengthy career now thinking about those kinds of problems.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Emphasizes that marketplace experimentation/data practices evolved over time, underscoring the value of long-term iteration and learning.

quotes.topic_title: What marketplaces really sell: removing transaction costs
quotes.text: But that's not what the platform is selling. That's a really important distinction.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Reframes marketplace value away from the obvious “product” and toward the underlying job the platform does.

quotes.topic_title: What marketplaces really sell: removing transaction costs
quotes.text: But Uber and Airbnb are selling you the taking away of something, which is a weird thing to think about. What they're taking away is the friction of finding a place to stay. They're taking away the friction of finding a driver.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: marketplaces win by removing friction rather than “selling” the underlying good/service.

quotes.topic_title: What marketplaces really sell: removing transaction costs
quotes.text: In economics, we call those things transaction costs.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Gives practitioners a precise term (“transaction costs”) to diagnose and design what their marketplace should reduce.

quotes.topic_title: What marketplaces really sell: removing transaction costs
quotes.text: And it's an important observation, because what that means is the marketplace's customers aren't just the people buying the rides, they're buying the listings. Actually, the hosts are Airbnb's customers, and the drivers are also Uber's customers. So both sides of the marketplace are the customers of the platform.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable reminder for marketplace builders: optimize product and incentives for both supply and demand as true customers.

quotes.topic_title: What marketplaces really sell: removing transaction costs
quotes.text: That when you're an entrepreneur starting a marketplace or thinking about your business model, I think you can be wildly off if you forget that that's the thing that's fundamentally your value proposition.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Direct guidance: anchor strategy and business model on transaction-cost reduction or risk building the wrong product.

quotes.topic_title: Why data science underpins marketplace flywheels
quotes.text: And these frictions that are getting taken away, they're getting taken away because of data and data science. So I really want to highlight three pieces of this for people, which I want you to think of them as a cycle.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Frames marketplace improvement as a repeatable, data-driven cycle that systematically removes friction.

quotes.topic_title: Why data science underpins marketplace flywheels
quotes.text: One of them is finding people to match with.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Defines the first core marketplace problem—candidate discovery—as a distinct, solvable step in the data loop.

quotes.topic_title: Why data science underpins marketplace flywheels
quotes.text: Then there's making the match.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Separates ranking/selection from discovery, clarifying that marketplaces need different mechanisms for each stage.

quotes.topic_title: Why data science underpins marketplace flywheels
quotes.text: And then finally, we make matches. Well, what do the matches tell us, right?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Highlights the often-underused idea that outcomes are a primary data asset for improving future matching.

quotes.topic_title: Why data science underpins marketplace flywheels
quotes.text: Every single thing I just said, finding potential matches, making matches, and then learning about those matches, and then cycling back again, that is the data science in marketplaces.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Provides a concise, memorable definition of marketplace data science as a closed-loop system practitioners can implement.

quotes.topic_title: Why many marketplace ideas fail early
quotes.text: Many founders try to start a marketplace business, think about marketplace opportunities where they don't exist.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a core failure mode: forcing a marketplace model onto problems that may not structurally support it.

quotes.topic_title: Why many marketplace ideas fail early
quotes.text: And there's often these recurring failures of types of marketplaces that just don't work in an area.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a pattern-recognition approach—some categories repeatedly fail, suggesting underlying structural issues founders should investigate early.

quotes.topic_title: Why many marketplace ideas fail early
quotes.text: I was just writing a couple ideas down while you were chatting like cleaners, getting cleaners as a marketplace doesn't seem to work ever. Car wash, there's a classic failure too. Getting tasks done for you on demand as a marketplace seems to not often work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of marketplace categories that have historically struggled, useful as a caution list for founders evaluating ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Why many marketplace ideas fail early
quotes.text: I'm just curious if anything comes up of when someone is starting a marketplace or thinking about starting a marketplace business, what do you find are the most common flaws in, this is probably not going to work as a marketplace?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames a practical diagnostic question founders can use to pressure-test whether a concept truly fits a marketplace model.

quotes.topic_title: Why many marketplace ideas fail early
quotes.text: I'm a professor at Stanford, and there's a reason I'm not a successful scaled entrepreneur of marketplaces, and that's because I probably haven't unlocked the key to exactly the question you asked.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A candid reminder to be cautious about overconfident “expert” prescriptions and to validate marketplace theories in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Start with a wedge: UrbanSitter and oDesk examples
quotes.text: What I've found talking to people who want to start what they think is a marketplace is that they think too much about a marketplace before they're a marketplace. That in my view is the biggest failure mode.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that founders often over-index on “marketplace” mechanics before they have the prerequisites (like liquidity).

quotes.topic_title: Start with a wedge: UrbanSitter and oDesk examples
quotes.text: That was an incredible friction to address, which is literally just we accept credit card payments for babysitting. That's it, right?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Concrete “start with a wedge” example: solve one painful, narrow friction to get initial adoption before full marketplace dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Start with a wedge: UrbanSitter and oDesk examples
quotes.text: So what's the moral there? The moral is a marketplace business never starts as a marketplace business, because what we think of as a marketplace business is something which at scale is removing the friction of the two sides finding each other. But when you start, you don't have that scale.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Memorable framework: early-stage marketplaces must begin as something else because matching value only emerges at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Start with a wedge: UrbanSitter and oDesk examples
quotes.text: So when you start, you had better be thinking, "What's my value proposition in a world in which I don't have that scaled liquidity on both sides?"
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable prompt for founders to design an initial offer that works even without network effects.

quotes.topic_title: Start with a wedge: UrbanSitter and oDesk examples
quotes.text: At that point, liquidity isn't the game. It's asking, what's a problem that people in this space are facing that I can deal with when I'm not a scaled marketplace?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Operational mental model: prioritize solvable, standalone problems (e.g., trust tools) before trying to win on liquidity.

quotes.topic_title: Every founder can become a marketplace founder
quotes.text: I mean, something I've actually pressed hard on in my own way of thinking about this is that maybe we shouldn't talk about the concept of a marketplace founder. Really there's founders.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Reframes “marketplace founder” as a false category, pushing practitioners to design with platform optionality in mind from day one.

quotes.topic_title: Every founder can become a marketplace founder
quotes.text: And if that's the case, it means literally any founder is a marketplace founder. It'll be a choice they make after they grow as to whether they want to build a platform.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A mental model that treats platform-ization as a later strategic choice rather than an initial company type.

quotes.topic_title: Every founder can become a marketplace founder
quotes.text: And two is because that's the case, I think one of the other challenges I find founders struggle with is you don't want to overcommit your future.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable warning to avoid early decisions (especially monetization/trust positioning) that constrain future marketplace evolution.

quotes.topic_title: Every founder can become a marketplace founder
quotes.text: That meant that the longer that goes on, the less value the platform is adding into that relationship, but you're still pulling 10% of all the dollars. So what does that lead to? A word that most marketplace CEOs know well is disintermediation, which is where you were intermediating between the two parties, and now disintermediation means that essentially they're like, "Hey, we don't need you anymore."
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Explains a common marketplace failure mode: value delivered declines over time while take-rate stays constant, incentivizing users to bypass the platform.

quotes.topic_title: Every founder can become a marketplace founder
quotes.text: My favorite example is we had some stuff delivered from IKEA by a Thumbtack worker once, and my wife is like, "Oh, thanks a lot. You're so reliable." He's like, "Hey, great. Here's my business card. Ever need me again? Just call the number on the back." And that was it. Thumbtack got their one lead gen, and then we didn't need the platform anymore.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Concrete story illustrating disintermediation in the wild and why lead-gen-only monetization can be fragile.

quotes.topic_title: Social contracts with sellers: Substack vs eBay
quotes.text: And at this point, over 80% of my subscribers come from Substack's network.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete data point showing how a platform can justify its take rate by materially driving demand for sellers/creators.

quotes.topic_title: Social contracts with sellers: Substack vs eBay
quotes.text: So they've built this marketplace element exactly as you're describing, where they just found, "Here's a pain point, writers need more subscribers. How do we help them drive subscribers?"
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable playbook: identify the seller’s biggest bottleneck and build product/network features that directly solve it.

quotes.topic_title: Social contracts with sellers: Substack vs eBay
quotes.text: the sellers on eBay who had matured with the platform, who had grown with it, had come to develop certain expectations about what their lives on that platform would look like.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Framework for platform governance: long-tenured sellers form implicit expectations that become constraints on future changes.

quotes.topic_title: Social contracts with sellers: Substack vs eBay
quotes.text: So when you now reach in and you say, "I'm going to completely change the rules of the game in which your business model operates," from the perspective of those sellers, that's a breaking of a social contract that's been developed over a very long time.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Memorable warning that fee/rule changes can be perceived as violating an implicit social contract, risking backlash and churn.

quotes.topic_title: Social contracts with sellers: Substack vs eBay
quotes.text: But I think for every one of those, there's an eBay warning sign that you can trap yourself a little bit.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that even successful value-add moves can create long-term lock-in to seller expectations and limit future flexibility.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing: liquidity test and when you’re not a marketplace
quotes.text: So the litmus test I like to give to someone who claims to me that they're building a marketplace business or they're a marketplace founder is do you have what I would call scaled liquidity on both sides of your platform?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Defines a clear diagnostic test founders can use to validate whether they truly have a marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing: liquidity test and when you’re not a marketplace
quotes.text: The smell test is scaled liquidity asks, "Do I have a lot of buyers and a lot of sellers on my platform, or do I only have one of these two, or do I have neither?" If you don't have both, you could call yourself whatever you want to call yourself, but at this moment in time, you're not a marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable reframing that prevents premature “marketplace” thinking and forces focus on actual liquidity.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing: liquidity test and when you’re not a marketplace
quotes.text: There's no shame in not being a marketplace. Scaling a business is scaling a business. If that's the way to do it, do it.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable permission to pursue the most effective growth path rather than forcing a marketplace model too early.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing: liquidity test and when you’re not a marketplace
quotes.text: If you decide you want to be a marketplace, then at that moment when you've got a lot of buyers, but not a lot of sellers, or a lot of sellers, but not a lot of buyers, the choice you're facing is, how do I take advantage of having that one side scaled to attract the other side?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Gives a practical decision point and method: scale one side first, then use it to pull in the other.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing: liquidity test and when you’re not a marketplace
quotes.text: So to take Uber as an example, they would walk into a new city, and one thing that Uber was commonly known for doing this was back in the days when really Uber Black was the only service is they just hand out coupons for free rides at events, parties, things like that, to take people home. And that was a way of saying, "Hey, we're subsidizing the drivers in the city. That's our scaled side. Now we're going to use that subsidized driver base to attract riders."
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Concrete example of using subsidies and one-sided scale to kickstart the two-sided flywheel in a new market.

quotes.topic_title: Market vs firm: when to own or curate supply
quotes.text: The way we talk about it often is a distinction between a market or a firm.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Introduces a core framework for deciding whether to run a marketplace or vertically integrate as a firm.

quotes.topic_title: Market vs firm: when to own or curate supply
quotes.text: Well, if markets are so efficient, why do we need firms? If markets are efficient at matching labor up with things that need to get done, why would you ever need a firm?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prompt that surfaces when marketplaces break down and why tighter control can win.

quotes.topic_title: Market vs firm: when to own or curate supply
quotes.text: And that's one of the earliest recognitions that transaction costs are a real thing. And that's one of the things that firms are solving for.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Gives the economic rationale for when firms outperform markets: reducing transaction costs and friction.

quotes.topic_title: Market vs firm: when to own or curate supply
quotes.text: Hey, for your frictions, the best resolution to that might not be to have a marketplace. It might actually be to have very tightly controlled labor.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: if your product depends on reliability/quality, consider employment or strong control instead of pure marketplace dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Market vs firm: when to own or curate supply
quotes.text: So I think there's some curation that needs to happen of that relationship. Does that mean full employee? Maybe not. But it does mean you have to think a little bit about exactly as you brought up, what's the nature of curation of your labor pool?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Highlights a middle path between marketplace and employment: curated matching/continuity as a design lever (e.g., healthcare/physical therapy).

quotes.topic_title: Where data scientists add leverage: decisions over predictions
quotes.text: But the problem with that way of thinking is actually predicting what their lifetime value is isn't really the question. The question is, how much more are they going to spend on my platform because I sent them that promotion?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Reframes common LTV targeting from predicting outcomes to estimating incremental lift from an intervention.

quotes.topic_title: Where data scientists add leverage: decisions over predictions
quotes.text: That's a very different thing. It's a differential rather than an absolute. I'm not interested in their absolute LTV. I'm absolutely interested in the difference in their LTV because I sent them this promotion.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Provides a crisp mental model—optimize for deltas (treatment effects), not levels (predictions).

quotes.topic_title: Where data scientists add leverage: decisions over predictions
quotes.text: Prediction is inherently about correlation. But when we ask people to make decisions, we're asking them to think about causation.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Defines the core distinction practitioners should internalize when moving from ML models to business impact.

quotes.topic_title: Where data scientists add leverage: decisions over predictions
quotes.text: And so the first and most important thing that I feel very strongly about in what would I get a data scientist to do is no matter who they are, even if it was that person in the weeds thinking about building this prediction model for hiring, get them to be thinking in the back of their mind always that their goal is to help the business make decisions. And that the distinction between causation and correlation matters a lot.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for DS work: anchor modeling efforts to decision-making and causal impact, not just accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Causal inference in ranking and matching quality
quotes.text: Maybe the right frame of reference for this, and the word that an academic would use is causal inference. So what we're changing from is machine learning to causal inference.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Introduces a core mental model shift: evaluate marketplace algorithms via causal impact, not just predictive ML accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Causal inference in ranking and matching quality
quotes.text: And when I think about the distinction between two different ranking algorithms, I don't want to be only comparing them in terms of how well they recreate the choices people made in the past. The way I'm really going to evaluate those is in my market, does one of those lead to better matches or more matches than the other one, right?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to compare ranking systems: optimize for downstream marketplace outcomes rather than offline fit to historical behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Causal inference in ranking and matching quality
quotes.text: So Airbnb as a business, what are the most obvious core metrics? It's bookings and revenue. So you're going to want to ask a very basic question. If I use the ranking algorithm Lenny just developed last night versus the ranking algorithm Ramesh developed last week, does Lenny's ranking algorithm lead to more bookings than Ramesh's ranking algorithm?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of causal evaluation framed as an A/B-style business question tied to core metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Causal inference in ranking and matching quality
quotes.text: And it's so important to put it that way starkly, because that's so different a question than, does Lenny's ranking algorithm do a better job of predicting over the last two years what bookings people made than Ramesh's ranking algorithm?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive trap: better offline prediction can be the wrong objective compared to causal impact on bookings.

quotes.topic_title: Causal inference in ranking and matching quality
quotes.text: So you're comparing two different algorithms not through their ability to recreate the past, but their ability to make matches in the future that can be objectively evaluated to say, "Hey, I increased the value of the business. I actually made better matches this way."
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Provides a practitioner-ready evaluation principle for matching systems: measure future match quality with objective outcomes, not historical imitation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth and product-learning discipline, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes the dual goal of moving faster without sacrificing analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform, where I could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of self-serve experimentation enabling faster iteration by reducing dependencies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out of the box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: use better stats + self-serve analysis + reporting to shorten experiment duration and analysis bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces the “A/B testing flywheel” mental model—sharing learnings compounds future experiment ideas and velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation culture: avoiding local maxima and incentives traps
quotes.text: Now all that said, I am also someone who feels pretty strongly about this exact issue that you're raising. It's just, you can't experiment your way out of everything.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A clear warning that experimentation has limits and must be complemented by higher-level strategy and judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation culture: avoiding local maxima and incentives traps
quotes.text: What I generally believe is we're risk averse on both these two dimensions, that what people decide to test in a world that has promoted experimentation for everything tends to be more incremental by design. Okay? And we'll come back to that actually, answer the because in a second. So that's one. And two is people tend to run experiments for a long time, and probably longer than they should.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic framework: teams get stuck with incremental tests and slow cycles, which blocks discovery of bigger wins.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation culture: avoiding local maxima and incentives traps
quotes.text: Companies have incentives. And in companies that really go all in on experimentation, one of the things that gets wrapped up in that is the incentives around experiments. Because if you go all in on experiments, a common thing you'll see is data scientists get judged based on how many wins they had that quarter. How do you get more wins?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Highlights an incentives trap where “win-counting” pushes teams toward safer, smaller experiments rather than meaningful learning.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation culture: avoiding local maxima and incentives traps
quotes.text: So you could see that there's a big incentive problem there, because the culture that says it's okay to fail big actually requires changing the terminology of wins. This is one of the things I hate most in A/B testing, I have to say.
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: Actionable cultural advice: shift language and evaluation away from “wins” to enable bigger, riskier bets.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation culture: avoiding local maxima and incentives traps
quotes.text: Experimentation is always very hypothesis driven. It's about, what are you learning?
quotes.speaker: Ramesh Johari
quotes.context: A methodology reminder that reframes experiments as learning vehicles, not just optimization contests.
